ODID http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 15. Qualitative Research Assistant - Young Lives Study (117439) http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/about/vacancies/current-vacancies/qualitative-research-assistant-young-lives-study-117439 Young Lives is a 15 year study of childhood poverty. It is core-funded by the UK Department for International Development (DFID), to provide policy relevant evidence on the changing nature of childhood poverty in Ethiopia, India (Andhra Pradesh and Telangana), Peru and Vietnam.

The Research Assistant will work collaboratively with researchers and policy staff in Oxford and the four Young Lives study countries. She/he will analyse longitudinal qualitative data, prepare summary reports and literature reviews, and support senior researchers in writing. She/he will assist with other administrative tasks related to maintaining a very large database of qualitative data and generally promoting qualitative research within Young Lives and publicly.

Applicants should have a Master\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds degree in a relevant social science discipline and experience of conducting research with children and families in developing countries. They should have substantial experience of analysing qualitative data.\ufffd\ufffd They should have strong writing and communications skills with experience of writing for publication. They need to be able to work collaboratively as well as independently, and to manage multiple demands.

The post is full time and tenable for 12 months in the first instance. Part-time applicants (minimum 80% of full-time) will also be considered.

]]> No publisher Luci Cummings 2015-03-11T18:05:00Z Vacancy Research Officer - Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative (OPHI) (117382) http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/about/vacancies/current-vacancies/research-officer-oxford-poverty-and-human-development-initiative-ophi-117382 The Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative (OPHI) seeks a full-time, post-doctoral Research Officer who will join the team working on multidimensional poverty measures. The Research Officer will contribute to OPHI's multidimensional poverty measurement activities by adapting existing and developing new research methodologies and materials, including questionnaires and surveys as well as measurement design, and by supporting partners who are implementing OPHI methodologies.\ufffd\ufffd The post holder will undertake academic research on multidimensional poverty analysis, and disseminate the results in teaching, seminars, briefings, and presentations.

Qualifications include: a doctorate in economics or another social science with strong quantitative background (completed or due to be submitted before the start date of this post), and experience of using STATA; the ability to lead training activities and provide technical consultations and to collaborate in the preparation of research publications; and strong interpersonal skills and the ability to relate across cultures and disciplines. \ufffd\ufffdThe post requires overseas travel of approximately 60 days a year, and is tenable for one year with the possibility of renewal, to start as soon as possible.

]]> No publisher Luci Cummings 2015-02-27T14:36:45Z Vacancy Departmental Lecturership in the Politics of Forced Migration (117071) http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/about/vacancies/current-vacancies/departmental-lecturership-in-the-politics-of-forced-migration-117071 The Oxford Department of International Development seeks applications for a one-year, full-time Departmental Lecturership in the Politics of Forced Migration, primarily to cover the sabbatical leave of Professor Matthew Gibney. \ufffd\ufffdThe Departmental Lecturer will provide teaching and supervision on the MSc course in Refugee and Forced Migration Studies, as well as carry out research in this field. \ufffd\ufffdThe post is tenable from 1 September 2015 or as soon as possible thereafter, until 31 August 2016.

Applicants should have: a doctorate in political science (or in another discipline if the applicant\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds work uses a political science approach) with a focus on the politics of forced migration, completed or due to be submitted before the start of appointment; a strong knowledge of issues relevant to forced migration and the ability to lead a compulsory course on the Politics of Forced Migration on the MSc in Refugee and Forced Migration Studies; \ufffd\ufffdproven ability and experience necessary to teach high-achieving and challenging graduate students in a multi-disciplinary environment and to carry out student assessment, examination and course design; an active research record in the field of forced migration and political studies; an academic publication record commensurate with stage of career; the ability to present research findings effectively to fellow professionals or other informed members of the public; and the ability to contribute effectively to the administrative work of the department and the ability to innovate and work effectively with colleagues as part of an multi-disciplinary team.

]]> No publisher Luci Cummings 2015-02-25T17:54:27Z Vacancy Olof Palme Lectures http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/events-1/special-events/olof-palme-lectures No publisher Jo Boyce 2015-01-08T16:18:46Z Seminar Alumni Profiles http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/alumni/alumni-profiles-1/alumni-profiles See what our alumni have gone on to do after their degrees on our ODID graduates page.

If you are a former student, we would love to find out more about what you are doing now \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd please download and fill out the Alumni Profile Form below and return to alumni@qeh.ox.ac.uk, to feature on this page.

  • Alumni Profile Form
]]> No publisher Jo Boyce 2014-11-19T16:15:00Z QEHPage Stay in Touch http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/alumni/stay-in-touch To keep up with all the latest news on departmental research, events, appointments and more you can follow us on Twitter and Facebook:

Alumni can also join one of our course-based LinkedIn groups to connect with other former students:

MPhil in Development Studies

MSc in Economics for Development

MSc in Global Governance and Diplomacy

MSc in Migration Studies

MSc in Refugee and Forced Migration Studies

We are also always keen to hear what alumni are doing \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd if you are a former student of the department and have news you would like us to feature on the website and social media, please email alumni@qeh.ox.ac.uk.

]]> No publisher Jo Boyce 2014-11-19T16:15:00Z QEHPage Alumni Profiles http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/alumni/alumni-profiles-1 No publisher Jo Boyce 2014-11-19T16:11:41Z Folder alumni http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/alumni No publisher Rachel Crawford 2014-11-19T16:11:30Z QEH Folder Alumni http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/alumni/alumni ODID students have gone on to pursue a fascinating range of careers after graduation \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in academia, international institutions, government agencies, NGOs, the private sector and more.

We are keen to maintain links with our alumni to find out more about what they are doing and to help them stay in touch \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd with each other and with the department.

We are planning an alumni programme that will include an alumni magazine and regular events, so keep an eye on this page for more information!

In the meantime, Oxford alumni can keep up-to-date with alumni news generally and find out about the University's own programme, which includes lots of events, activities and benefits, on the University of Oxford Alumni webpages.

]]> No publisher Rachel Crawford 2014-10-20T10:45:00Z Videoq MPhil Course Video http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/study/study-video/mphil The two-year MPhil in Development Studies provides a rigorous and critical introduction to development as a process of managed and unmanaged change in societies in the global South. The course is an excellent preparation for a career in development policy or practice or for further study in the field.

]]> No publisher Rachel Crawford 2014-07-10T09:05:00Z Videoq Higher Education in India: How High, How Far? http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/events-1/podcasts/odid-lectures/chaudhuri-100614 Speaker/Convenor: Sukanta Chaudhuri (Jadavpur University, Kolkata)

Date: 10 June 2014 17:00

Location: Seminar Room 2, ODID, 3 Mansfield Road

Series: ODID Distinguished Visitor Lectures

Sukanta Chaudhuri was educated at Presidency College, Kolkata, and Oxford University. He was Professor of English first at Presidency College and then at Jadavpur University, Kolkata, where he is now Professor Emeritus. At Jadavpur, he founded the interdisciplinary School of Cultural Texts and Records. His primary areas of interest are the European Renaissance and textual and editorial studies. His last major publication was The Metaphysics of Text(Cambridge, 2010), and he is currently editing A Midsummer Night\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Dream for the Third Arden Shakespeare. He is active in digital humanities, and was planner and chief co-ordinator of the Tagore online variorum Bichitra. He has also translated widely from Bengali to English. He has held various positions in academic planning and administration, a subject on which he writes regularly in the Indian press. He is currently Visiting Fellow at All Souls College, Oxford.

]]> No publisher Rachel Crawford 2014-06-11T08:30:00Z Audio A Precariat Charter: From Denizens to Citizens http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/events-1/podcasts/odid-lectures/standing-150514 Speaker/Convenor: Professor Guy Standing (SOAS)

Date: 15 May 2014 14:00

Location: Seminar Room 2, ODID, 3 Mansfield Road

Series: ODID Distinguished Visitor Lectures

The precariat, consisting of millions facing insecurity, unstable labour and loss of rights, is alienated and angry. Throughout history, class-based revolt has led to charters of demands, from the Magna Carta to South Africa\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Freedom Charter. It is now time for a Precariat Charter.

Guy Standing, Professor of Development Studies at SOAS, University of London, will be talking about his new book.

Professor Standing is a founder and co-President of the Basic Income Earth Network, an NGO promoting basic income as a right. He has held chairs at the Universities of Bath and Monash (Australia) and was previously Director of the Socio-Economic Security Programme of the International Labour Organisation.

]]> No publisher Rachel Crawford 2014-05-19T10:30:00Z Audio Toby Porter http://www.qeh.ox.ac.uk/study/alumni/all-courses/toby-porter I see the year's break I took from humanitarian work in 1999 to complete the MSc in Forced Migration as a key turning point in my career. Fresh from six years of field work, I benefited hugely from the opportunity to step back and place my experience from crises such as Rwanda and Kosovo into a broader historical and policy context. This gave a breadth and a depth to my analysis that I think stayed with me, and allowed me to take on much more senior roles in the future, having resumed full-time work. Soon after my Master's, I was doing high-level policy consulting for the UN and other think thanks, which in turn led me to be recruited by Save the Children to lead their humanitarian work globally.

The course offered me just the right mix of new topics as well as the chance to reflect upon and share my own experience. I relaxed, and loved the chance to resume full-time education in Oxford. I remain friends with many of the teaching staff as well as my fellow students that year, and look back on my decision to take the course as a really good one that has not only benefitted me, but, far more importantly, has had an indirect positive impact on those I have tried to help in the course of the more challenging jobs I have held since I left.

]]> No publisher Jo Boyce 2014-03-17T13:25:00Z StudentDetail
